Making Sense of
Making Parole in
New York State

by Alexandra McGlinchy

The New York State Board of Parole holds the unique authority to decide on the release of eligible individuals incarcerated under the Department of Corrections and Community Supervision (DOCCS). This independent entity is tasked with making decisions on parole, establishing the terms for parole, and revoking it if those terms are not adhered to.

According to DOCCS, parole board interviews may include questions about past criminal behavior, records during custody, participation in programs, future aspirations, and plans upon release. It's not specified which answers or plans are most likely to secure parole.

So, what really influences a candidate's chances for parole? Are factors like age, race, the nature of the crime, time served, the facility, and the county of commitment significant in determining the outcomes of parole interviews?

With this project, I aim to uncover patterns in parole decisions using publicly available data on incarcerated individuals and their parole interviews from September 2021 to September 2023. This exploration seeks to provide insights into how the Board of Parole operates and what factors may tip the scales in thier decision-making process.

A key point to note: This analysis is based solely on quantifiable, publicly accessible data. It doesn't include private criminal records, detailed explanations of parole board decisions, or other immeasurable factors like the specifics of the crime, political context, the individual's demeanor during the hearing, their perceived remorse, the robustness of their release plan, or the level of community support or opposition. Therefore, while this analysis provides valuable insights, it is important to recognize that it represents only a partial view, limited to the measurable aspects of the parole interview process.

I've found that there are endless ways to explore, analyze, and visualize this data. This reality is both beautiful and overwhelming.

Lets begin.

Over these two years, the Board of Parole of New York State conducted 0 interviews with persons eligible for parole.

There were a total of 9,077 individuals interviewed.

2,760 of those individuals were interviewed more than once.

Taking a look at the outcomes
of these interviews, approximately
47% were denied parole,
34% were granted parole.

The remaining interviews were either postponed, or not yet given a decision / given a decision of "other".

For our purposes, we're going to focus on the interviews with decisions of either denied or granted.

We'll look at variables of interest such as race, age, gender, interview type and how they relate to these interview decisions.

First, check out the makeup of these groups by race/ethnicity.

Scroll over the pie charts to explore.

White people make up
40.7% of the granted interviews and
30.6% of the denied interviews.

Black people make up
37.9% of the granted interviews and
45.6% of the denied interviews.

15% more interviews of black people were denied than interviews of white people.

Is this difference significant? Or could it be due to the fact that there were more interviews of black people than white people?

To account for one group being represented more in the data, in this chart each bar represents 100%* of that group.

This shows the rate at which each racial group is either denied or granted parole.

Scroll over the bars to explore.

*These bars do not actually equal 100% of the total group's population. Interviews that received a postponement or other decision are not represented here.

Interviews of black people are
8.26% more frequently denied than granted parole and
19.6% more frequently denied parole than interviews of white people.

Interviews of white people are
1.05% more frequently denied than granted parole and
10.46% more frequently granted parole than interviews of black people.

Here's the same chart displaying age groups.

Scroll over the bars to explore.

Interviews of people under 25 are
32.91% more frequently denied than granted parole and
9.2% more frequently denied parole than interviews of people aged 45-54.

Interviews of people aged 45-54 are
5.18% more frequently denied than granted parole and
18.5% more frequently granted parole than interviews of people under 25.

Up til now, we've seen data to suggest a few things that, albeit interesting, aren't entirely surprising to me (given history of this country).

First, we've seen that interviews with black people are more often denied than those of any other race. And interveiws with white people are more often granted than those of any other race.

We've also seen that parole grants tend to trend upwards with age.

Let's look at something I found to be a little more surprising.

This density chart represents the estimated density of the data as related to the individual's proportion of sentence served at the time of the interview.

If we are to assume that as one serves more of their sentence (the proportion of their sentence served increases), they have a better chance of making parole, we would expect to see a normal distribution as shown with the red line.

The distribution seen here suggests that there's a sweet spot for being granted parole at around 25% of max sentence served and a spike in denials of those who've served well over half of their maximum sentence.

Here you can toggle between time served, age entered and age to see each variable's distribution for both the denied and granted groups.

The similarities between distributions of granted and denied for these variables suggests that they're not determining factors in whether someone is granted or denied parole.

Another variable we've yet to look at is the type of interview.

INITIAL: initial appearance, PIE hearings (parole immediately eligible), merit time hearings, early conditional parole for deportation hearings, medical hearings, and supplemental merit hearings.

REAPPEAR: Reappearances - release was previously denied.

OTHER: Parole violation hearings, hearings held after parole is granted but the parole board receives new information that prompts them to reconsider their decision, hearings held after successful appeal of parole denial.

Initial and reappear make up around 97% of the total interviews, so let's take a closer look at just these two interview types.

Check out how the total initial and reappear interviews are composed by interview decisons.

Initial interviews are granted parole 2.2% more than reappear interviews.

Not only are reappear interviews granted parole less often than initial interviews, but they are also denied parole more often.

Reappear interviews are denied parole 7% less than initial interviews.
